definition:
Let $K$ be a number field with ring of integers ${\mathcal{O}}_K$. Then
the Dedekind zeta function of $K$ is the analytic continuation of the
following series:
$$\zeta_K(s)=\sum_{I\subset{\mathcal{O}}_K} (N^K_{{\mathbb{Q}}}(I))^{-s}$$
where $I$ ranges over non-zero ideals of ${\mathcal{O}}_K$, and
$N^K_{{\mathbb{Q}}}(I)=|{\mathcal{O}}_K:I|$ is the norm of $I$.

This converges for $\Re(s)>1$, and has a meromorphic continuation to the
whole plane, with a simple pole at $s=1$, and no others.

The Dedekind zeta function has an Euler product expansion, $$\zeta_K(s)=
\prod_{{\mathfrak{p}}}\frac{1}{1-(N^K_{{\mathbb{Q}}}({\mathfrak{p}}))^{-s}}$$
where ${\mathfrak{p}}$ ranges over prime ideals of ${\mathcal{O}}_K$.
The Dedekind zeta function of ${\mathbb{Q}}$ is just the Riemann zeta
function.
